instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message:
Hi all

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.38V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.400V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.325V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>:5.122V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>:3.325V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>:5.119V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.325V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 5.122V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>: 3.325V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>:5.118V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>:3.319V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.797V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>: 1.496V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL>:1.320V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.506V
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>: 0.747V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0</SIGNAL>: 0.902V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>: 1.045V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.052V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCCADPLL</SIGNAL>: 1.058V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.320V

[B]<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>:0V[/B]
In diode mode red probe to gnd: 0.011V,
Resistance to gnd 14.5 Ohm when not pwered but slowly drops to 1.5 Ohm when the charger is plugged: No short to gnd for me.
In the mean time the fan speeds up to the max speed.
CPU <CHIP>U1000</CHIP> over heating can't let the finger on it.

[B]<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP</SIGNAL>: jumping diretly from 2.5V to 8.40V in loop[/B]

Tomorrow I'll pass the board in an UC bath,as I see some test pads corroded around CPU. Maybe crap and corrosion under CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message:
"Resistance to gnd 14.5 Ohm when not pwered but slowly drops to 1.5 Ohm when the charger is plugged:"
STOP to measure continuity into powered board!!!

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.38V
[B]<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP</SIGNAL>: jumping diretly from 2.5V to 8.40V in loop[/B]"
???
Is the same power rail...

If CPU get very hot without any voltage on VCORE, that is bad thing.
It receives few other voltages, but should not overheat wihtout VCORE.
You could have a bad CPU now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no cpu vcore
threads.message:
DEAD CPU!!!!!!!

You can close the topic thanks
